person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: State and Private Forestry, Forest Service

title.narrative: South Africa - Training on Risk-Based Inspection and Phytosanitary Certification

description.narrative: ITRCB as part of its 2016 work plan for Phytosanitary capacity building activities approved the funding to implement a workshop for 25 participants in Risk Based Inspection and Phytosanitary Certification of plant and plant products in Southern Africa. This technical training is principally dedicated to Phytosanitary Inspectors.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: Southern Africa - 3rd Int'l Symposium of TEAM, Tephritid workders of Europe, Africa , Middle East

description.narrative: The TEAM symposiums take place every four years and aim to bring together scientists in Europe, Africa and the Middle East involved in research on fruit flies (tephritids) and to provide a platform that will encourage a spirit of communication, collaboration and sharing of knowledge and expertise for the benefit of the three regions and its people

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: South Africa- Tuta absoluta Surveillance and Management in Southern African Region

description.narrative: Promote regional detection, surveillance and suppression of Tuta absoluta to safeguard agricultural productivity, thereby promoting food security and reducing the use and impact of harmful agrochemicals. Also supports harmonized surveillance and monitoring of Tuta absoluta in the region in order to mitigate the risk of further spread. Facilitate the presentation of ongoing basic and applied research problems related to Tuta absoluta at appropriate regional scientific fora.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: HLB technical exchange visit with Citrus Stakeholders

description.narrative: Citrus greening or Huanglongbing (HLB) is considered one of the most destructive citrus diseases globally and has accounted for substantial economic losses in Asia and the Americas.The project supported a technical visit to South Africa and Swaziland by an APHIS HLB subject matter expert (SME) in order to raise awareness levels and mobilize support for phytosanitary mitigations to address the imminent threat of HLB. Engagements between the HLB SME, NPPO officials and related stakeholders facilitated an exchange of information on perspectives and experiences with the management of HLB in the United States, so that officials are better equipped in terms of their emergency response and Phytosanitary control measures in addressing the threat of HLB.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Agricultural Quarantine Inspection User Fee Account
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Agricultural Quarantine Inspection User Fee Account

title.narrative: Surveillance, Detection and Management of Citrus Greening Disease Workshop

description.narrative: This workshop aims to increase regional capacity to combat the spread of citrus greening in southern Africa and includes training in surveillance, response, and management for entomologists, plant pathologists and industry stakeholders. The workshop is also intended to bolster communication between relevant stakeholders, so that information related to citrus greening, and other emerging pests and diseases, can be more effectively shared. Slowing and limiting the spread of both the pathogen and its insect vector will result in more favorable outcomes for commercial and smallholder citrus producers. Note: This activity is tentatively planned and may be delayed due to the ongoing COVID-19 situation.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Agricultural Quarantine Inspection User Fee Account

description.narrative: This activity will promote regional early warning, detection, surveillance and management of emerging pests of concern in southern Africa to safeguard agricultural productivity, thereby promoting food security and trading opportunities. The project also aims to strengthen communication between National Plant Protection Organizations in the region and enhance their surveillance and early warning systems and capabilities. Note: This activity is tentatively planned and may be delayed due to the ongoing COVID-19 situation.

title.narrative: Scientific Cooperation Research Program - Soil Health

description.narrative: The Scientific Cooperation Research Program supports joint research, extension, and education projects lasting up to two years among domestic and international agricultural professionals. These projects address issues including agricultural trade and market access, animal and plant health, biotechnology, food safety and security, and sustainable natural resource management.
